Award.AwardTitle: The 39th Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports participation in the thirty-ninth annual Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE) at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in Daytona Beach, Florida on October 26-27, 2019. Starting its first conference at Virginia Tech in 1981, the SEARCDE is held annually by various institutions in the Southeast region of the United States. The conference provides a unique platform for all researchers in the field of differential equations and applications and related fields to share their research experiences, to disseminate recent results, and to establish collaborations. The SEARCDE aims to promote research and education in all aspects of differential equations and applications and related fields. Many research experts, beginning researchers, and graduate students will be brought together to give talks, to exchange recent research and new ideas, to discuss open problems in the area of differential equations and applications and related fields. Beginning researchers and graduate students will be able to learn from plenary and invited speakers, interact with experts, and meet with colleagues to discuss working problems. Women, minority, and underrepresented groups are strongly encouraged to participate in the SEARCDE.

The primary focus of the conference is to create a friendly atmosphere for participants to share their findings and recent progress, explore new techniques and discuss open problems. The thirty-ninth SEARCDE will focus on three major areas: linear and nonlinear analysis of differential equations, mathematical fluid mechanics and mathematical biology, and numerical and computational methods of partial differential equations. There will be five internationally renowned experts giving three one-hour plenary talks and two thirty-minute invited talks on these topics. Several researchers will give twenty-minute contributed talks divided into six parallel sessions. Junior researchers and graduate students whose research interests are closely related to these topics will benefit greatly from this conference. Information about the conference can be found at https://commons.erau.edu/searcde/2019-39th/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 39th Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE) was held at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach Campus, FL from October 26 to October 27, 2019. The primary objective of the conference was to promote research and education in the field of differential equations and applications by bringing together experts, recent PhDs and graduate students working on differential equations and applications and related areas.  

The conference featured 3 one-hour plenary talks, 2 thirty-minute invited talks and 72 twenty-minute contributed talks. The plenary speakers were Jerome Goldstein from the University of Memphis, Maia Martcheva from the University of Florida and Alina Chertock from the North Carolina State University. They are internationally recognized experts in their research areas. The plenary talks comprised of history, recent developments and future directions in the topics of theoretical, computational and applied differential equations. In addition, two renowned experts, S. Roy Choudhury from the University of Central Florida and Robert Stephen Cantrell from the University of Miami delivered invited talks.  Experienced researchers, recent PhDs and graduate students presented the contributed talks. These talks were grouped into six parallel sessions under various categories.

The participants came from various regions of the United States as well as from out of the United States. There were 110 participants including several ERAU faculty and student volunteers.  A significant number of participants attended every talk and had time to discuss the recent progress and future directions of the area of the talks.  The conference provided a friendly atmosphere for interactions and discussions between established researchers, early career researchers and graduate student and was a unique platform for all participants to share their research findings and learn from experts.  A survey was taken during the conference and it is evident from the survey that the conference was well liked and appreciated the variety of talks and the preparation of the conference. The coffee break, dinner and the breakfast time were utilized for discussions and for exploring common research topics and collaborations. The NSF funding provided the support for plenary speakers, invited speaker, and 46 other participants, which included PhD students and early career mathematicians and mathematicians from underrepresented groups.  The NSF funding greatly helped the participants who did not have personal and departmental funding so that they could participate, and present their research, benefit from others talks, and establish new connections and collaborations.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/09/2020
Modified by: Keshav R Acharya
